content.description: A fun balancy arete.  Hardest moves come in the middle.
content.location: The right arete of the left boulder at The Dome.

content.description: A very aesthetic line that will test everything from your finger strength to your memory due to the small holds and tough sequence. The problem starts low on the arete (left hand undercling, right hand sloper below the crimp jug) and arcs all the way up to a great topout.
content.protection: A couple of crashpads and a spotter
content.location: On the right arete of the twin overhanging boulders in the main area.

content.description: start stretched across the face and move up
Sit under Rodeo. Compression tick tack your way through awful holds, building to a crux slap to join the stand start.

Pull on at the head-height bulge and make a series of compression moves to gain a thin flake jug. Carefully trend right up the dirty lip to top out as for White Lines.

Grade varies depending on your height, but probably easier than White Lines for most people.

climbs.name: One Small Step
climbs.fa: Idk. Maybe me, but I doubt it.

content.description: Sit start to Stretch Armstrong. Left hand on the lowest left edge of the face, just above the left foot. Right hand as high as you can reach on the right side of the face. Right foot smear. Compress upward, thuggishly, into Armstrong.
content.location: Northeast face of the Armstrong boulder, SDS.

content.description: Starting with a long righthand toss with abysmal feet to a good sidepull, this problem gets right to business.  After the powerful initial move you'll face a series of slaps up the sloping overhanging arete with your left hand, some tricky crimps with your right, and more miniscule footholds.  The topout is blissfully straightforward but still difficult.
content.location:
On the left side of the boulder with

The Upsetter

.  In other words, the left arete of the right twin boulders.

content.description: Start on the large juggy rail near the center of the face and move up and right.  Pull up over the bulge and then prepare to either move your right hand up to a bad pinch before tossing a pretty desperate move up to a sloping rail, or if you're a bit taller just go for it with your left hand first.
content.location: The route is on the overhanging face just before you reach the center of the main area.  Walk down the trail from the parking area past a couple of outlying boulders, go through the woods and the small scree field, and you'll see it on your left.

content.description: Start sitting with a good left hand crimp and a jug for the right hand. Move through some cool incut crimps to a long move to a juggy sloper, from the sloper negotiate a couple easy yet insecure moves to the top. Good stone and enjoyable movement.
content.location: On the "prow" of The Stretch Armstrong boulder.
